citations.narrative:
Two perimeter fences of at least 8 feet were not sufficient to prevent a pack of three pit bull dogs from entering the facility
the morning of May 17, 2023. According to the licensee, the pack of dogs climbed the fences and took one wallaby out of
the enclosure after killing it. The wallaby was in a covered shed open on one side surrounded by double 8 ft fencing that
was intact and secure, however the dogs were reportedly able to climb into the enclosure with the wallabys and take one
of the five. The keeper was cleaning the enclosures and tried to scream and hit on the fence to get the dogs to leave, per
the licensee. The keeper was at great risk to themselves while trying to scare off the dogs. The county sheriff department
was called during the incident however the dogs left the enclosure by the time they arrived. The Sheriff department was
able to follow the dogs to their home and made contact with the owner of the dogs, according to the licensee. The
licensee conveyed that within hours of the predation the sheriff deputy contacted the licensee to advise the three pit bulls
were permanently removed from the residence and would not be a threat to his livestock anymore.
The facility has been vigilant in mitigation efforts by constructing double fencing higher (8ft) than AWA regulations require
at 6ft and providing on-site keeper during the day and the owner at the house next to the enclosures every day and
evening. All fencing surrounding the pastures have been reinforced where needed including rocks/bricks surrounding the
bottom of fences to prevent animals from digging under and possibly making contact with the animals. The licensee is
working on electric fencing as additional protection.
The licensee must provide a perimeter fence that is of sufficient height to keep animals out and prevent animals from
gaining entry into the enclosures making contact with regulated animals.
There have been no further incidents of predation from May 17, 2023 through to the writing of this inspection report.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with licensee.
n

narrative:
3.127(d)  Critical
   
Facilities, outdoor. 
Two perimeter fences of at least 8 feet were not sufficient to prevent a pack of three pit bull dogs from entering the facility 
the morning of May 17, 2023. According to the licensee, the pack of dogs climbed the fences and took one wallaby out of 
the enclosure after killing it. The wallaby was in a covered shed open on one side surrounded by double 8 ft fencing that 
was intact and secure, however the dogs were reportedly able to climb into the enclosure with the wallabys and take one 
of the five. The keeper was cleaning the enclosures and tried to scream and hit on the fence to get the dogs to leave, per 
the licensee. The keeper was at great risk to themselves while trying to scare off the dogs. The county sheriff department 
was called during the incident however the dogs left the enclosure by the time they arrived. The Sheriff department was 
able to follow the dogs to their home and made contact with the owner of the dogs, according to the licensee. The 
licensee conveyed that within hours of the predation the sheriff deputy contacted the licensee to advise the three pit bulls 
were permanently removed from the residence and would not be a threat to his livestock anymore.  
 
The facility has been vigilant in mitigation efforts by constructing double fencing higher (8ft) than AWA regulations require 
at 6ft and providing on-site keeper during the day and the owner at the house next to the enclosures every day and 
evening. All fencing surrounding the pastures have been reinforced where needed including rocks/bricks surrounding the 
bottom of fences to prevent animals from digging under and possibly making contact with the animals. The licensee is 
working on electric fencing as additional protection. 
 
The licensee must provide a perimeter fence that is of sufficient height to keep animals out and prevent animals from 
gaining entry into the enclosures making contact with regulated animals. 
 
There have been no further incidents of predation from May 17, 2023 through to the writing of this inspection report. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with licensee.
